Keyboard Class

Definition

Represents the keyboard device.

In this Article

public static class Keyboard
Inheritance
System.Object
Keyboard

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
Equals(Object,Object)
GetHashCode()
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()

Remarks

The Keyboard class provides keyboard-related events, methods, and properties that provide information regarding the state of the keyboard.

Each of the events that Keyboard defines as an attached event is also re-exposed by the base element classes UIElement and ContentElement as a new routed event. Generally, it is more convenient to handle keyboard events for an application on UIElement and ContentElement, rather than using the Keyboard events. For details, see Input Overview.

In order for an element to receive keyboard input, the element must be focusable. Most UIElement derived objects are focusable by default. Otherwise, to make an element focusable, set the Focusable property on the base element to true. For more information on the base elements, see Base Elements Overview.

Panel classes, such as StackPanel and Canvas, set the default value of Focusable to false. Therefore, for these objects to obtain keyboard focus, Focusable must be set to true.

Keyboard focus refers to the object that is receiving keyboard input. The element with keyboard focus has IsKeyboardFocused set to true. There can be only one element with keyboard focus on the entire desktop. Logical focus refers to the object within a focus scope that has focus. For more information on focus, keyboard focus, and logical focus, see Input Overview and Focus Overview.

The static members of the Keyboard class delegate to the primary KeyboardDevice of the calling thread, so they are not necessarily thread-safe.

Fields

GotKeyboardFocusEvent

Identifies the stem.Windows.Input.Keyboard.GotKeyboardFocus attached event.

public static readonly System.Windows.RoutedEvent GotKeyboardFocusEvent;

Remarks

Routed event identifiers are created when routed events are registered, and the result is stored as a field on the class that registers the routed event. These identifiers contain an identifying name, owner type, handler type, routing strategy, and a utility method for adding owners for the event. You often use these identifiers as parameters to event system methods, to identify a particular routed event.

Properties

DefaultRestoreFocusMode

Gets or sets the behavior of Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) when restoring focus.

public static System.Windows.Input.RestoreFocusMode DefaultRestoreFocusMode { get; set; }
Value
RestoreFocusMode

An enumeration value that specifies the behavior of WPF when restoring focus. The default in RestoreFocusMode.

FocusedElement

Gets the element that has keyboard focus.

public static System.Windows.IInputElement FocusedElement { get; }
Value
IInputElement

The focused element.

Remarks

Keyboard focus refers to the object that is receiving keyboard input. The element with keyboard focus has IsKeyboardFocused set to true. There can be only one element with keyboard focus on the entire desktop. Logical focus refers to the object within a focus scope that has focus. For more information on focus, keyboard focus, and logical focus, see Input Overview and Focus Overview.

An element with keyboard focus also has logical focus for the focus scope the element belongs to. An element with logical focus may or may not have keyboard focus.

Modifiers

Gets the set of ModifierKeys that are currently pressed.

public static System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys Modifiers { get; }
Value
ModifierKeys

A bitwise combination of the ModifierKeys values.

Remarks

ModifierKeys is a bit field enumeration, so it is possible for multiple modifier keys to be pressed at the same time. Use bit operations to determine the exact set of modifier keys pressed.

PrimaryDevice

Gets the primary keyboard input device.

public static System.Windows.Input.KeyboardDevice PrimaryDevice { get; }
Value
KeyboardDevice

The device.

Remarks

This property supports the WPF infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.

ClearFocus()

Clears focus.

public static void ClearFocus ();

Remarks

If focus is within a Win32 window, WPF calls the ClearFocus method on restoration of focus when a menu is closed.

When leaving menu mode, Win32 focus is returned to the hosted child HWND, and no element has WPF focus.

Focus(IInputElement)

Sets keyboard focus on the specified element.

public static System.Windows.IInputElement Focus (System.Windows.IInputElement element);
element
IInputElement

The element on which to set keyboard focus.

Returns
IInputElement

The element with keyboard focus.

Remarks

For an element to receive keyboard input, the element must be focusable. To make an element focusable, set the Focusable property on the base element to true. For more information on the base elements, see Base Elements Overview. Panel classes, such as StackPanel and Canvas, set the default value of Focusable to false; therefore, for these objects to obtain keyboard focus, Focusable must be set to true.

Keyboard focus refers to the object that is receiving keyboard input. The element with keyboard focus has IsKeyboardFocused set to true. There can be only one element with keyboard focus on the entire desktop. Logical focus refers to the object within a focus scope that has focus. For more information on focus, keyboard focus, and logical focus, see Input Overview and Focus Overview.

An element with keyboard focus also has logical focus for the focus scope the element belongs to. An element with logical focus may or may not have keyboard focus.

GetKeyStates(Key)

Gets the set of key states for the specified key.

public static System.Windows.Input.KeyStates GetKeyStates (System.Windows.Input.Key key);
key
Key

The specified key.

Returns
KeyStates

A bitwise combination of the KeyStates values.

Remarks

KeyStates is a bit field enumeration; therefore, it is possible for a key to be in multiple states. For example, a key could be in the pressed state as well as in the toggled state. Use bit comparison operations to determine the exact state or states the key is in.

The Keyboard class provides a number of static methods which can also be used to obtain key state information. The methods are: IsKeyDown, IsKeyUp, and IsKeyToggled.

IsKeyDown(Key)

Determines whether the specified key is pressed.

public static bool IsKeyDown (System.Windows.Input.Key key);
key
Key

The specified key.

Returns
Boolean

true if key is in the down state; otherwise, false.

Remarks

The GetKeyStates method can be used to determine the set of states of a specific key.

IsKeyToggled(Key)

Determines whether the specified key is toggled.

public static bool IsKeyToggled (System.Windows.Input.Key key);
key
Key

The specified key.

Returns
Boolean

true if key is in the toggled state; otherwise, false.

Remarks

The GetKeyStates method can be used to determine the set of states of a specific key.

IsKeyUp(Key)

Determines whether the specified key is released.

public static bool IsKeyUp (System.Windows.Input.Key key);
key
Key

The key to check.

Returns
Boolean

true if key is in the up state; otherwise, false.

Remarks

The GetKeyStates method can be used to determine the set of states of a specific key.
